subject: Re: [junit] Counting junit test failures/errors
msgSnippet: ... As I mentioned earlier, there are categories of tests that tolerate what I call partial failures , the best example being sending packets over an
messageBody:
On 8/25/06, J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains@...> wrote:
>
>
> I work this way: either I tolerate test failures or I don't. I tolerate
> test failures for customer tests, but not for programmer tests. I've
> never wanted to tolerate "a few" failures, for any value of "a few" in
> code that I committed to source control.


As I mentioned earlier, there are categories of tests that tolerate what I
call "partial failures", the best example being sending packets over an
unreliable network or a protocol that doesn't guarantee delivery (e.g. UDP),
or cross-talk packets in a clustered application, or simply sending SMS
messages, to name a few examples.

Of course, there is also the case where you know that a few tests are broken
and they need to remain so for a certain period of time, but that's probably
a slightly different topic.

--
Cédric
http://testng.org


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
